questions.text: A 70-year-old lady complains of being infested with body lice. Her dermatologist could not find any signs of infestation but she insists that she could feel the lice moving on her skin and brings a matchbox full of skin scrapings for examination. Which of the following descriptions is most appropriate?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ekbom’s syndrome Delusional infestation (Ekbom’s syndrome) is a delusion of parasitic (macroscopic) infestation with classical matchbox sign .

Highyeild:

This can predate the onset of dementia . It may or may not be associated with a somatic tactile hallucination .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A & B. It is not the same as compulsive skin picking , where the psychopathology is one of compulsion and not a delusion . Option: C. In factitious dermatitis , patients seek medical attention without an obvious monetary gain in order to be in a patient role. They induce skin lesions using chemicals or medicinal products in order to ‘become a patient’.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male is bought with complaints of irrelevant talking in the workplace. On talking to the patient, it's seen that the patient will go off topic while answering the question and will never answer the asked question in the end. You establish it as a disorder of thought. Consider the following statements regarding disorders of thought process- Overinclusion of trivial or irrelevant details that impede the sense of getting to the point is known as tangentiality. Thoughts associated with their sounds instead of meaning are called clang associations. Circumstantiality means giving a reply that is appropriate to the topic without actually answering the question. Derailment is a sudden breakdown in both the logical connection between ideas and the overall sense of goal-directedness. Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Only 2 and 4 are correct Point: 1. This statement is describing Circumstantiality. Circumstantiality is the Overinclusion of trivial or irrelevant details that impede the sense of getting to the point. Point: 2 . Thoughts associated with their sounds instead of meaning are called clang associations is correct Point: 3. This statement is describing Tangentiality. Tangentiality is said when, in response to a question, the patient gives a reply that is appropriate to the general topic without actually answering the question . Example: Doctor: "Have you had any trouble sleeping lately?" Patient: "I usually sleep in my bed, but now I'm sleeping on the sofa." Point: 4. Derailment is a sudden breakdown in both the logical connection between ideas and the overall sense of goal-directedness.

questions.text: A patient who has taken lithium for some months discontinues it and says ‘the ocean needs a sail as a rat needs a tail, so write your exam and don’t fail, results will be out in the mail’. Which of the following symptoms is he exhibiting?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Rhyming In clang associations , thoughts are associated by the sound of words rather than their meaning, that is through rhymes (rail/ tail/ sail) or puns (one word with two meanings rose = flower/ past tense of rise). Clang associations can form the basis for the flight of ideas .

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option: C. Neologism is the formation of new words which doesn’t have any dictionary meaning. Option: B. Punning- an expression that makes deliberate use of verbal ambiguity, generally for humorous effect. Option: D. Pressured speech is not a formal thought disturbance; it is rather a disturbance in the stream of thought .

questions.text: A Patient came to the doctor with his wife. His wife says that he thinks that his relatives are conspiring against him. She tries to convince him that it is not so, but still her husband doesn't believe her and says that they will kill him. Which type of delusion does the patient has?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Delusion of persecution The patient believes he is being conspired against or persecuted in some way.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Delusions of guilt or sin - The patient believes that he has committed some terrible sin or done something which is unforgivable. Option: B. Delusions of jealousy - The patient believes his spouse is having an affair with someone Option: D. Religious delusions - The patient is preoccupied with false beliefs of a religious nature.

questions.text: A 36-year-old male is brought by his wife with complaints of increased shouting and hitting her and their son as he feels that they are trying to poison him and kill him. He is scared that they’ll steal his brilliant ideas and kill him. On talking, you didn't find any motive to do so and cannot correlate his story. There was an error in:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Thought content The given case depicts the presence of Delusions which is a disorder of thought content. Thought content is essentially what thoughts are occurring to the patient. This is inferred by what the patient spontaneously expresses , as well as responses to specific questions aimed at eliciting particular pathology.

Highyeild:

Delusions are false, fixed ideas that are not shared by others and can be divided into bizarre and non-bizarre . Common delusions include grandiose, erotomanic, jealous, somatic, and persecutory.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option: A. The thought process differs from thought content in that it does not describe what the person is thinking but rather how the thoughts are formulated, organized, and expressed . The normal thought process is typically described as linear, organized, and goal-directed . Option: B. Thought form is due to disorganized thinking and is seen in the form of disorganized speech . Option: D. all of the above.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient came for an examination. The doctor asks him his name and he say's I’m Raju. Then the doctor asks where he came from, he says I’m Raju. The doctor asks what do you do, He says I’m Raju. What does this represent?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Perseveration Perseveration is the tendency to focus on a specific idea or content without the ability to move on to other topics . The perseverative patient will repeatedly come back to the same topic despite the interviewer's attempts to change the subject.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Thought blocking refers to a disordered thought process in which the patient appears to be unable to complete a thought. The patient may stop mid sentence. Option: C. Thought insertion . The patient believes that thoughts that are not his [her] own have been inserted into his [her] mind. Option: D. Thought withdrawal . The patient believes that thoughts have been taken away from his [her] mind.

questions.text: A 32-year-old nurse believes that one of the hospital's attending physicians is in love with her. It began when the physician entered a room where she was standing and he pointed at her. At that moment she became convinced that he was in love with her and tried to transmit his love through the looks he gave her and through the tone of his voice. Which type of Delusion she is suffering from?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Delusion of Erotomania In Erotomania, which has also been referred to as de Clérambault syndrome or psychose passionnelle , the patient has the delusional conviction that another person , usually of higher status, is in love with him or her .

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option: B. Persecutory delusions. The patient believes he [she] is being conspired against or persecuted in some way. Option: C. Delusions of guilt or sin . The patient believes that he [she] has committed some terrible sin or done something unforgivable. Option: D. Delusions of jealousy . The patient believes his [her] spouse is having an affair with someone.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient came to OPD and tells the physician that over the past 4 weeks, his television has been talking about him. From what specific type of delusion is this patient suffering?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Delusion of reference The patient believes that insignificant remarks or events refer to him [her] or have some special meaning.

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Thought insertion is a delusion in which the patient believes thoughts from some Option: B. Somatic delusions refer to a external entity are placed in his mind. delusion about the patient's body, for example, a common belief is that one's body parts are diseased. Option: C. Thought broadcasting is the belief that one's thoughts can be heard or somehow known by others without direct communication.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman is admitted to the hospital. Her relatives complained that she is not eating anything. On asking her she says she doesn't have an intestine. What delusion is this known as?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Nilhistic delusion Patients with Nihilistic delusional disorder or Cotard syndrome complain of having lost not only possessions, status, and strength but also their heart, blood, and intestines. The world beyond them is reduced to nothingness.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option: B & C. The delusion in Capgras syndrome is the belief that a familiar person has been replaced by an Other have described variants of the Capgras syndrome, namely, the delusion that persecutors or familiar persons can assume the guise of strangers ( Fregoli s phenomenon ). Option: D. Cacodemonomania is the delusion that one is poisoned by an evil spirit.

questions.text: A 36-year-old educated person is asked the meaning of “A leopard can’t change its spots”. He replied, “A person can’t change his innate character”. What aspect of their thinking is demonstrated?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Abstract thinking Abstract reasoning is the ability to shift back and forth between general concepts and specific examples . Having the patient identify similarities between like objects or concepts (apple and pear, bus and airplane, or a poem and a painting) as well as interpreting proverbs can be useful in assessing one's ability to abstract . Cultural and educational factors and limitations should be kept in mind when assessing the ability to abstract.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option : B. When the person is asked the meaning of a proverb and they answer in the literal sense and do not think about what the proverb actually means metaphorically. This is concrete thinking . Option: C. Thought content is essentially what thoughts are occurring to the patient. This is inferred by what the patient spontaneously expresses, as well as responses to specific questions aimed at eliciting particular pathology. Option: D. Thought process differs from thought content in that it does not describe what the person is thinking but rather how the thoughts are formulated, organized, and expressed.

questions.text: A 41-year-old woman, is a known case of Bipolar Mood Disorder. She had 3 episodes of mania in the past. Which of the following would be an expected mental status observation in this patient if she presented during one of these episodes?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Flight of ideas The symptoms during manic episodes include distractibility, grandiose delusions, flight of ideas, agitation, decreased need for sleep, talkativeness, or pressure of speech .

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option B – Ideas of reference are seen in delusional disorders , including schizophrenia . They involve the belief that casual events, people’s remarks, etc. are referring to oneself when, in fact, they are not. Option C – Thought blocking refers to the abrupt cessation of speech before the idea is finished. This is not seen in manic patients . Option D – Word salad is the term for an incoherent collection of words seen in patients with Broca’s aphasia .

questions.text: A 60-year-old male was brought by his son for behavioral complaints. While examining the patient, the Psychiatrist asked the patient what he had for breakfast. The patient replied- “Breakfast was hot. Hot like the sun. Sun shines in the sky. Sky should have been purple. Purple flowers are my favorite. Flowers smell so good.” The disorder of thought process seen is –
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Flight of ideas Flight of ideas is a succession of multiple associations so that thoughts seem to move abruptly from idea to idea ; often (but not invariably) expressed through rapid, pressured speech .

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option A: Derailment (Synonymous with loose associations ) is a breakdown in both the logical connection between ideas and the overall sense of goal-directedness. The words make sentences, but the sentences do not make sense. Option B: Circumstantiality is the Overinclusion of trivial or irrelevant details that impede the sense of getting to the point. Option D: Tangentiality is said when, in response to a question, the patient gives a reply that is appropriate to the general topic without actually answering the question . Example: Doctor: "Have you had any trouble sleeping lately?" Patient: "I usually sleep in my bed, but now I'm sleeping on the sofa."

questions.text: A 44-year-old was brought to the hospital by his son with complaints of irrelevant talking and inability to identify family members. There is also a history of aggressive behavior with the neighbors and delivery person. While examining the patient, he says that the neighbors and his wife are trying to know his idea and are trying to harm him. The disorder of the possession of thought seen in this condition is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Thought broadcast Thought broadcast is a condition where the patient feels that others ( many people) are trying to know the patient’s ideas without the patient speaking out.

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option: B. In this type, the patient feels that the other person gets to know the patient’s ideas without the person speaking. Option: C.
